title: Boojum forest
text:
The Boojum forest is an area in central <a href="Baja%20California">Baja California</a>, Mexico, near <a href="Catavina%2C%20Baja%20California">Catiavinia</a> known for <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> <a href="flora">flora</a> so bizarre and grotesque in appearance that the area was named after mathematician/logician <a href="Lewis%20Carroll">Lewis Carroll</a>'s imaginary landscape story, "<a href="The%20Hunting%20of%20the%20Snark">The Hunting of the Snark</a>".
The area is characterized by almost no rainfall, as opposed to the two coasts of the Baja Peninsula, exotic plants such as "<a href="Fouquieria%20columnaris">Fouquieria columnaris</a>", which can grow up to 50 feet tall with an 18-inch diameter. Large rounded granitic boulders appear and so do the columnar cacti such as "<a href="Ferocactus%20gracilis">Ferocactus gracilis</a>", huge fleshy "red blooded" elephant trees, "<a href="Bursera%20microphylla">Bursera microphylla</a>", huge endemic ocotillo ("<a href="Fouquieria%20peninsularis">Fouquieria peninsularis</a>") with flaming red flowered tipped ends, and the world's largest cactus, the columnar Cardon, "<a href="Pachycereus%20pringlei">Pachycereus pringlei</a>".
Location.
The forest is about 220 miles south of Tijuana along highway one in Baja California, Mexico.
